story:
The Impact

On Indiegogo's suggested outline for "the pitch" they have this section last, however, we realize we are not on here raising money to eradicate some horrible disease or feed hungry children or help the elderly pay their medical bills.  Believe us when we say we have looked through the campaigns here and are awestruck by the compassion and generosity on display in many of the fundraising efforts. We wanted to let you know, right here at the beginning, what we can pledge: If you support us in starting our publishing company we will not take that for granted.  Once the business is running and is successful we promise we will remember it was built by donations and as such will support other campaigns that are  performing charitable work such as reading programs to help illiterate adults and outreach programs that work with at risk youth.  

Though we are asking you to help us start a for profit company, it will be a company with a social conscience and it will help those community and non-profit organizations that are doing much needed and admirable work.  From our perspective this is for the love of books, writing and reading, not profit or fame.

Us

Laura and Dave are cousins who grew up much more like brother and sister.  Though Laura was always the bigger book worm, from an early age, the dream was for Dave to write and Laura to illustrate.  As we all know, life sometimes has its own ideas of how things should work.  It turns out Laura wrote the book... and a very good one at that.     

Our Plan... in Brief

Since it is nearly impossible for new writers to get noticed by the large publishing houses, we have decided to start our own publishing company.  Our initial project will be to get Laura's first book on the market.  Since this book is the first of a series, future goals will be, of course, to publish future works (one of which is complete, another of which is half finished).  Once we have our feet wet and are able to build capacity, we'll start to look for other great, undiscovered talent to help.  Remember, Harry Potter was initially published by a small house because the larger houses wouldn't take a chance on an unknown author.

Depending on how much we are able to raise and, if needed, borrow, will largely determine our printing and marketing plans for the first book.  This is discussed more in the following section.   

What We Need

It is said, "you have to spend money to make money."  Therein lies the problem so many who have had dreams have encountered.  We need start up funds - plain and simple.  We absolutely believe in this project and are, of course, investing what we can of our own funds, but, like most, we do not have thousands of dollars laying around in disposable, fluid assets.  If we did, we wouldn't be coming to you with this Indiegogo campaign.

The very basic initial costs, which include, filing the paperwork to form the company and securing ISBN numbers and their corresponding barcodes are reasonable... approximately $1200.

The majority of money raised in this campaign will go to the larger obstacle of initial printing fees and marketing efforts.  We have set a goal of $5000.  This will not fully fund our effort, but will give us a good start.  And we wanted a somewhat reasonable goal.  Of course, every dollar raised here is a dollar we don't have to borrow.  

Exact costs for printing are difficult to project as printing fees can vary widely based on many variables.  One choice to be made is between the two primary printing methods, each with advantages and disadvantages.  Print on Demand is a newer method that many smaller publishers and self-published authors have used to help control costs.  While this method has cheaper up front costs because it does not require that you order in large numbers, the quality can be lower and per copy costs are actually higher.  The time honored method of off-set printing has low per copy costs and better quality, but typically requires orders of larger quantities.  Aside from causing higher up front costs, this also raises the issue of storage space.  With these two methods available, we can print as few as a couple of copies to thousands in our initial run.  These decisions will have to be made when we have a better idea of the resources available.  

Ideally we will have enough funds on hand to utilize off-set printing.  If we meet our goal of $5000 that means we will be able to print approximately 2000 books but will leave little left for other expenses.              

What You Get

Because we realize how generous you are being by contributing to help us achieve a dream, we have some awesome perks as our way of saying thanks.

- $25 gets you a huge thank you and a signed and numbered copy from the initial print run of our first published work.  Think of it as pre-pre-ordering.

- $75 gets you the above plus our undying gratitude and your name on the "Thank You" page of our first publication.

- $200 gets you the above plus a kiss on the hand from us to you (metaphorically speaking, literally only if we happen to run into you and you want one) and the right to name a minor character in a future work of fiction.

- $450 gets you the above plus our highest admiration and the right to name a major character in a future work of fiction.

-$1000 gets you the above plus us groveling at your feet for being unworthy of your generosity AND a signed Special Edition hard cover copy of the original published work with a page personally recognizing your contribution that will be printed only for those who contribute at this level.  This will, of course, be a collectors item some day.

Note on numbered copies: They will be given out with priority given to contribution level first and then date of contribution.

 

A Little Taste...

Prologue

As she slowly pulled the door shut, the shaft of light from the top of the stairs shrank, until the only thing illuminated were the two fingers of his left hand. 

The door clicked shut a moment later, plunging him into complete darkness and for the first time, showing her the light.

 

Chapter 1

He’d passed by the house at least twice a day for the past two weeks while riding his bike and every time she was there, he watched her out of the corner of his eye. She never looked up as he passed and he never slowed enough to make himself noticed. 

But he wanted to.

He wished she would at least glance his way so he’d have an excuse to stop.

And being just 15, he didn’t have the courage, gumption or enough of what some would call an approaching sense of self, to talk to her first.

Until now.

Because now he had a reason. 

Oh, it was a crappy, concocted, ‘set the chain of events in motion’ kind of reason, but again, being 15, he thought it was pure gold.

He pretended his tire was going flat.  It was simple. It was ideal. It was perfect … and also rather stupid.

In the quick and easy act of leaning forward to stare at the tire, he managed to over-balance, tip sideways, knock into the small picket fence surrounding the front yard and take out several small, purple flowered bushes. 

This of course not only made her look up but she stood quickly, knocking the pile of paper in her lap to the ground.

He righted himself quickly, turned a lurid shade of red in embarrassment and said the first thing that popped in his brain, “so, you like paper huh?”

After this, he just stood, wondering how odd it would be if he began banging his head on the concrete and wailing in sheer idiocy at his previous and hopefully last statement ever.

The girl, standing stock still on the porch steps, didn’t come over, didn’t open her mouth, didn’t seem to even be breathing. She just stared until the boy thought it better for everyone if he just got the hell out of there and found a new bike route.

Giving a small, pathetic wave by way of apology for disturbing her, he turned and continued down the street.

Later that night, he sat at his family’s dinner table long after his brothers had run off to various summer entertainments: bike-riding, evening jobs, video games. He sat so long that his mother came over and tried to pry out of him exactly why he’d been so quiet. But prying tonight would be fruitless. And soon, his mother just shook her head, ruffled his hair and asked if he’d like to join them in a game of Monopoly.

With a shake of his head, “no thanks. I’ve still gotta go cut the lawn. It’s my turn.”

“Well, maybe when you’re done, see if Nate’ll help with the trimming. If I recall, he owes you for taking out the trash last week.”

Finally smiling, “good thinkin’.”

The next day, he found himself following his usual route. He wasn’t sure why but for some reason, there he was, pedaling along, feeling an overwhelming nervousness and excitement mixed with a healthy dose of embarrassment.

He wanted to see her again. And he wasn’t disappointed. As he approached the house, there she was, this time a book propped on her lap rather than the paper. She was looking right at him as he swallowed hard and put on the brakes.

“No paper today?” She shook her head and held up the book so he could see the title, Algebra for Dummies, “huh? Just some light summer reading?”

She shook her head again, although this time a voice followed, “summer school.” Now, normally, he’d have responded with something but after hearing her voice, coupled with the piercing green eyes, he managed to forget just exactly how to speak. So he instead stood, staring openly at her until she finally, finally, finally, broke into a small smile, “you okay there?”

And he crashed back to Earth.

Shaking his head, “um, yeah. Sorry. Didn’t mean to stare.”

“It’s all right. Algebra pretty much makes me catatonic as well.”

Returning the smile, “I’m Jack.”

“Would you laugh if I said my name was Jill?”

“Probably.”

“Just checking.”

Slightly intrigued now, he hesitated before asking, “is, um, your name Jill?”

“No. I just wondered if you’d laugh.”

Shaking his head, “so, you gonna make me guess ‘cause we could be here an awful long time?”

Setting her book on the porch, she walked towards him, “I imagine you might end up trying names like Bertha or Clementine and I just couldn’t handle that so,” holding out her hand, “I’m Emily.”

After shaking her hand in an oddly formal gesture, she excused herself quickly, “I hate to go but I’ve gotta get ready for work. I’m sorry.”

“You have a job?”

She nodded her head, “yeah. I work at a Chinese place at night, washing dishes and bussing tables.”

“Are you 16?”

“Nope.”

Figuring her mom had signed some kind of work release, he moved on, “what about your Algebra?”

“That’s for after I get home.” Turning towards the house, she stopped and faced him again, “why didn’t you ever stop to say hello before?”

Feeling the heat burn his cheeks, he couldn’t believe the honest answer that dropped from his mouth, “I guess I was scared.”

“Of me?”

“No. Of those vicious snapdragons you’ve got by the fence. Grabby little things.”

“Well, I’ll hold them back next time I see you. Promise.”

“Then I might just have to stop and say hi again.”

“You’ll probably find me trying to solve for X.”

“I could probably help with that.”

Nodding, “maybe.”

And with that, she disappeared around the back of the house after scooping up the books from the porch.

And with that, Jack decided that Emily could very well be the most beautiful name in the world.

It took three more days of drive-bys before she was back outside on the porch.

"Hey there."

"Hi."

"I haven't seen you for a few days. Are they trying to drown you in the egg-drop soup?"

She shook her head, "no, but this math is slowly beginning to kill me. You'd think it would sink in after awhile."

"Stuck huh?"

"More like buried deep with no hope of resurrection." Shrugging, "but I'll get it eventually. I always do."

"You know, I know somebody who knows pretty much what X equals all the time. Maybe I could convince him to help you."

"You know a guy?"

"Last I checked, he had an A or something like that."

"Would that be you?"

"Am I that transparent?"

"Just a little bit but I'll forgive you if you can tell me what a factorial is."

"Oh lord, do we have some work to do."

And so they sat.

And learned.

And talked just a little bit.

All across the worn top of the rickety old table on the porch.

And it was good.

An unspoken routine developed and by the end of the next week, Emily managed to get her first ever B on a math test. 

“We should celebrate.”

She looked at him, confused, “for a B?”

“Yeah. Are you kidding? Given what you didn’t know two weeks ago, I’d say that B is a miracle.”

This time, the look went from confused to bewildered to completely blank, “well, thanks for the help. But I think I’ve got it from here.”

Now it was Jack’s turn to look taken aback, “what? You’ve still got another test and a final to take.”

“I’ll be fine.”

Not sure what the hell had just happened, “wait? I think I missed something here. What’d I do?”

“I refuse to let anyone call me stupid ever again. You did and now we’re through.” Turning to go, “like I said, thanks for the help but I’ve got it from here.” Reaching out to stop her, the minute his hand touched her arm, she jerked away, “get off me.”

The anger behind those three words made him cringe back slightly and not wanting to do anything else to upset her, he walked away quietly.

It was an amazing thing, what happened next. Jack made it home and when he walked in, the house was quiet. Either the Earth had swallowed up the herd or they were all laying dead somewhere, victims of some stupid stunt involving catapults and flaming tennis balls.

Neither was true. All the younger ones were at the library for some afternoon programs and of course, his older brother was at work. 

That left him to find his mom, calmly sitting on the back porch, her feet up and a bowl of ice cream on her lap. 

Without a word, he came out the screen door and dropped down next to her. She finished the spoonful she was on and offered him the last little bit in the bowl, which he gladly slurped down.

“So, how’s Jack today?”

“Jack is beginning to wonder what makes girls freak out?”

“Ahhh. ‘Bout time you got around to her. I’ve been wondering how long you’d hold out before you cracked.”

“You knew?”

“Are you joking? You’ve been surreptitiously digging into old Algebra books, you disappear every day between 2 and 4 and you’ve been wearing clean shirts.”

“All that points to a girl?”

“Of course, that and while I was driving to the store the other day, I saw you sitting on a porch with someone.”

“I assume you didn’t tell the rest of them?”

She shook her head, “I was kind of hoping you’d tell me first. It’s nice to know something before the mob for once.”

He grinned at her, then remembered, “but I think I’m finished anyway so it doesn’t matter.”

“Finished? It’s only been a few weeks.” Turning, she pulled her leg up next to her, “what happened?”

With a shrug, “she got a B on her test and I told her we should celebrate. She asked why we’d do that ‘cause it was just a B. I told her that with what she didn’t know two weeks ago, a B was a miracle.”

“Okay.”

“Then she said something like ‘I refuse to let anyone call me stupid again’ then she walked away. I reached out to stop her and the minute my hand touched her, she panicked, said ‘get off me’ and went into her house.”

“You didn’t grab her did you?”

“No, I swear. I barely even felt her arm.” Demonstrating, “I’m amazed she even knew I touched her.”

Both turned towards the house as the commotion of 4 boys began to leak out the open windows, “so much for quiet.” Looking back at her son, “a piece of advice, something hurt her; from the sound of it, probably a lot of things. You’ve already walked away and I won’t say a thing if you stay away but …” with a tilt of her head, “maybe she needs a friend and I know you’re good at that.”

With a grin, she ruffled his hair and stood, heading into the chaos of the house while he sat back, his head on the cushion and his eyes closed, contemplating the complicated life of a 15 year old boy.

The next day, Jack had to watch the younger kids so he didn’t have a chance to find Emily but as luck would have it, she found him.

They’d all just gotten back from an extremely long bike ride and after dropping their bikes on the driveway and collapsing in various piles on the front lawn, all was quiet. 

That silence, however, was broken by a girl.

A girl with a voice that made Jack smile in spite of himself.

Sitting up on his elbows, he found her standing on the sidewalk, book in hand, “so, anyone here know any math?”

The other boys looked at each other in confusion as Jack pulled himself to his feet, “I know a little bit.”

And that’s how they ended up on a different porch on a different street, the same Jack and the same Emily, only this time, surrounded by talk of Ninjas and Spider-Man and the occasional friendly arm-wrestling match between the younger boys.

Jack only joined in when his ample knowledge of the ninja was needed to settle several arguments.

Emily could only smile, realizing that maybe people weren’t so bad after all.

Emily was gone before Mrs. Callaghan got home but from the look on her son’s face, it appeared that everything would be just fine and with a smile, she informed him that she would eventually have to meet this girl, for security purposes and all.

Slightly intrigued now, he hesitated before asking, “is, um, your name Jill?”
“No. I just wondered if you’d laugh.”
Shaking his head, “so, you gonna make me guess ‘cause we could be here an awful long time?”
Setting her book on the porch, she walked towards him, “I imagine you might end up trying names like Bertha or Clementine and I just couldn’t handle that so,” holding out her hand, “I’m Emily.”
After shaking her hand in an oddly formal gesture, she excused herself quickly, “I hate to go but I’ve gotta get ready for work. I’m sorry.”
“You have a job?”
She nodded her head, “yeah. I work at a Chinese place at night, washing dishes and bussing tables.”
“Are you 16?”
“Nope.”
Figuring her mom had signed some kind of work release, he moved on, “what about your Algebra?”
“That’s for after I get home.” Turning towards the house, she stopped and faced him again, “why didn’t you ever stop to say hello before?”
Feeling the heat burn his cheeks, he couldn’t believe the honest answer that dropped from his mouth, “I guess I was scared.”
“Of me?”
“No. Of those vicious snapdragons you’ve got by the fence. Grabby little things.”
“Well, I’ll hold them back next time I see you. Promise.”
“Then I might just have to stop and say hi again.”
“You’ll probably find me trying to solve for X.”
“I could probably help with that.”
Nodding, “maybe.”
And with that, she disappeared around the back of the house after scooping up the books from the porch.
And with that, Jack decided that Emily could very well be the most beautiful name in the world.
It took three more days of drive-bys before she was back outside on the porch. "Hey there."
"Hi." "I haven't seen you for a few days. Are they trying to drown you in the egg-drop soup?" She shook her head, "no, but this math is slowly beginning to kill me. You'd think it would sink in after awhile." "Stuck huh?" "More like buried deep with no hope of resurrection." Shrugging, "but I'll get it eventually. I always do." "You know, I know somebody who knows pretty much what X equals all the time. Maybe I could convince him to help you." "You know a guy?" "Last I checked, he had an A or something like that." "Would that be you?" "Am I that transparent?" "Just a little bit but I'll forgive you if you can tell me what a factorial is." "Oh lord, do we have some work to do."
And so they sat.
And learned.
And talked just a little bit.
All across the worn top of the rickety old table on the porch.
And it was good.
An unspoken routine developed and by the end of the next week, Emily managed to get her first ever B on a math test. 
“We should celebrate.”
She looked at him, confused, “for a B?”
“Yeah. Are you kidding? Given what you didn’t know two weeks ago, I’d say that B is a miracle.”
This time, the look went from confused to bewildered to completely blank, “well, thanks for the help. But I think I’ve got it from here.”
Now it was Jack’s turn to look taken aback, “what? You’ve still got another test and a final to take.”
“I’ll be fine.”
Not sure what the hell had just happened, “wait? I think I missed something here. What’d I do?”
“I refuse to let anyone call me stupid ever again. You did and now we’re through.” Turning to go, “like I said, thanks for the help but I’ve got it from here.” Reaching out to stop her, the minute his hand touched her arm, she jerked away, “get off me.”
The anger behind those three words made him cringe back slightly and not wanting to do anything else to upset her, he walked away quietly.
It was an amazing thing, what happened next. Jack made it home and when he walked in, the house was quiet. Either the Earth had swallowed up the herd or they were all laying dead somewhere, victims of some stupid stunt involving catapults and flaming tennis balls.
Neither was true. All the younger ones were at the library for some afternoon programs and of course, his older brother was at work. 
That left him to find his mom, calmly sitting on the back porch, her feet up and a bowl of ice cream on her lap. 
Without a word, he came out the screen door and dropped down next to her. She finished the spoonful she was on and offered him the last little bit in the bowl, which he gladly slurped down.
“So, how’s Jack today?”
“Jack is beginning to wonder what makes girls freak out?”
“Ahhh. ‘Bout time you got around to her. I’ve been wondering how long you’d hold out before you cracked.”
“You knew?”
“Are you joking? You’ve been surreptitiously digging into old Algebra books, you disappear every day between 2 and 4 and you’ve been wearing clean shirts.”
“All that points to a girl?”
“Of course, that and while I was driving to the store the other day, I saw you sitting on a porch with someone.”
“I assume you didn’t tell the rest of them?”
She shook her head, “I was kind of hoping you’d tell me first. It’s nice to know something before the mob for once.”
He grinned at her, then remembered, “but I think I’m finished anyway so it doesn’t matter.”
“Finished? It’s only been a few weeks.” Turning, she pulled her leg up next to her, “what happened?”
With a shrug, “she got a B on her test and I told her we should celebrate. She asked why we’d do that ‘cause it was just a B. I told her that with what she didn’t know two weeks ago, a B was a miracle.”
“Okay.”
“Then she said something like ‘I refuse to let anyone call me stupid again’ then she walked away. I reached out to stop her and the minute my hand touched her, she panicked, said ‘get off me’ and went into her house.”
“You didn’t grab her did you?”
“No, I swear. I barely even felt her arm.” Demonstrating, “I’m amazed she even knew I touched her.”
Both turned towards the house as the commotion of 4 boys began to leak out the open windows, “so much for quiet.” Looking back at her son, “a piece of advice, something hurt her; from the sound of it, probably a lot of things. You’ve already walked away and I won’t say a thing if you stay away but …” with a tilt of her head, “maybe she needs a friend and I know you’re good at that.”
With a grin, she ruffled his hair and stood, heading into the chaos of the house while he sat back, his head on the cushion and his eyes closed, contemplating the complicated life of a 15 year old boy.
The next day, Jack had to watch the younger kids so he didn’t have a chance to find Emily but as luck would have it, she found him.
They’d all just gotten back from an extremely long bike ride and after dropping their bikes on the driveway and collapsing in various piles on the front lawn, all was quiet. 
That silence, however, was broken by a girl.
A girl with a voice that made Jack smile in spite of himself.
Sitting up on his elbows, he found her standing on the sidewalk, book in hand, “so, anyone here know any math?”
The other boys looked at each other in confusion as Jack pulled himself to his feet, “I know a little bit.”
And that’s how they ended up on a different porch on a different street, the same Jack and the same Emily, only this time, surrounded by talk of Ninjas and Spider-Man and the occasional friendly arm-wrestling match between the younger boys.
Jack only joined in when his ample knowledge of the ninja was needed to settle several arguments.
Emily could only smile, realizing that maybe people weren’t so bad after all.
Emily was gone before Mrs. Callaghan got home but from the look on her son’s face, it appeared that everything would be just fine and with a smile, she informed him that she would eventually have to meet this girl, for security purposes and all.

story:
The Project

Q: What can you do with a degree in linguistics?
A: Tell me what you might want to do, and I will tell you how linguistics will help to take you there!

Having a background in linguistics gives you a unique set of analytical and communicative skills which are truly helpful in the world of work. But talking about these skills, and learning about how exactly you can apply them may seem overwhelming.  You may not know how to begin.  I want to help!  Bringing Linguistics To Work is a book written by a linguist, for linguists, and is about the linguists who have been forging career paths ahead of you.

Using case studies and activities based on real-life examples, Bringing Linguistics To Work shows you how others have applied their skills and training, how you can use story as a career exploration and education tool, and how you can bring linguistic skills to the search itself. If you're a new linguistics graduate, a grad student who's thinking about careers beyond academia, or just someone looking to present themselves in a new way, this book is for you.

This project has been designed to raise the funds to edit, print, and share the book with the linguistics community at large. Furthermore, this campaign will support the creation of supplemental online resources to be put up on Career Linguist, such as in-depth linguist interviews and short videos like this one, designed to give further guidance and inspiration to linguists seeking their career.

The Creator

I am Anna Marie Trester, the founder of Career Linguist, a blog and resource center for linguists interested in exploring careers beyond academia. I am an associate at the FrameWorks Institute in Washington, DC.

I received my Ph.D. in linguistics from Georgetown University and was the Director of Georgetown's M.A. Program in Language and Communication from 2008 - 2014, where I advised linguistics graduate students about applying their linguistic knowledge in professional contexts.

I have given workshops about careers for linguists to hundreds of linguistics students  and am a founding member of the Linguistics Beyond Academia Special Interest Group for the Linguistic Society of America. As a researcher, I have been published in journals including Language in Society, Discourse Studies and the Journal of Sociolinguistics, and am the co-editor (with Deborah Tannen) of Discourse 2.0: Language and New Media.

The Expenses

If I hit my target goal, I will be able to hire a professional editor to closely and carefully edit the entire book so as to have it ready for publication this summer.  Your contribution will pay her for her work and will also help to pay for a graphic designer in addition to printing and shipping costs for the first run of the book. Additionally, I will also be able to hire some freelance researchers and writers to help me gather more resources to share with our community on CareerLinguist for example career stories to share on Profiles in Linguistics, and more videos like this one. 

Risks and Challenges

Bringing Linguistics to Work has been drafted as a complete manuscript -- but it needs to be significantly edited and pared down.  I am excited about this pruning process and have contracted with an experienced and gifted editor, but this close, careful work is time-consuming, and will involve a significant investment of energy.  I want to have the book ready to print by the Fall, but as the process unfolds we may decide that it needs more time, and if we do, we will.  What is most important is to give you a clear book that maximally informs your career process.   In the meantime, I will be keeping you posted and will continue to share newly-minted resources on CareerLinguist.com!

If I do not hit my target goal, I will scale back the scope of all of the above, devoting as much initially to funding the editing of the book, and I will issue an e-book or pdf version so that it can still get out to those who would benefit from it. If I happen to go over my goal, I will be able to produce an even more beautiful book that is clothbound, letterpressed, foil-stamped, professional-grade, offset-printed, edge-gilded, archival-quality and acid-free, one that you will always treasure!  I will also be able to make even more of all of the resources I describe above for the community to use, and additionally, look for even more ways to build community, like hosting workshops or a virtual conference.


The Next Steps

I need your help to make this book happen. Any amount that you can donate is greatly appreciated, but it's just as important that we share this project with the entire linguistics community. Send this to your friends; post on social media; share it on your departmental listserv.

Follow Career Linguist on Twitter and Facebook

- https://www.twitter.com/careerlinguist
- https://www.facebook.com/careerlinguist

and, if you haven't already, please check out my website:

http://careerlinguist.com/

About the Video


And Crucially...
Thanks so much for your support. Here's to what comes next!

story:
In late 2011, REDEFINE shifted its focus from traditional music journalism to highlighting the ways in which art is inspired by and inspires other walks of life. Encouraged by the words of fine thinkers through the ages, we aim to create arts journalism which, like art itself, has wide-reaching transformative potentials for self and society.

Every article below has come from years of work with a completely voluntary staff.

With your help and support, we hope to make an even larger positive impact on the world with socially-conscious and expansive arts journalism.

 

By interviewing individuals with different roles and skillsets, we show how multiple minds collaborate on the same projects and highlight how various types of art intersect.

Album Covers Of The Year __ AUDIO-VISUAL
Artists, musicians, and labels discuss the complex creative process of album covers.

Music Video Features __ AUDIO-VISUAL
An ongoing series that gathers insight from directors and musicians.

I and I: A Collective Interview w/ Sun Araw, M. Geddes Gengras, Tony Lowe & The Congos __ MULTICULTURAL
A four-way interview with two American musicians, one Jamaican band, and one American director.

Orcas Band Interview: A Balance Of Majestic Forces
A sound and text analysis of two solo musicians on their first collaborative work together.

 

In 2005, REDEFINE dedicated an entire print issue to Hopeless Records’ Take Action Tour and its charitable cause: suicide prevention. We now regularly feature up-and-coming artists who are using their spheres of influence to help the world-at-large.

La Dispute Collect For Charity, Locally & Abroad
Vocalist Jordan Dreyer speaks on the band's impressive history of giving to organizations supporting disenfranchised youth.

Red Fang Benefit Portland Arts Education
Bassist Aaron Beam discusses the plight of funding loss in Portland schools and what Red Fang did to help.

Country-themed mixtapes and in-depth feature articles about regional music scenes encourage understanding across country lines, and bilingual articles grow that even more.

The Real Icelandic Music Scene __ MULTICULTURAL
An in-depth analysis of the Icelandic music scene featuring interviews from dozens of musicians and industry folks, plus three mixtape downloads with exclusive tracks available nowhere else.

Sun Airway / NAM Album Cover Artwork __ JAPANESE & ENGLISH + AUDIO-VISUAL + MULTICULTURAL
Interviews with Japanese art collective NAM and American musicians Sun Airway on the visual language of music.

Ikonoklasta Protests Against The Angolan Government __ PORTUGUESE & ENGLISH + MULTICULTURAL
An interview regarding political turmoil in Angola and one rapper's role in helping foster a youthful revolution.

Hands In The Dark Label Mixtape __ FRENCH & ENGLISH + MULTICULTURAL
One of our many exclusive mixtapes, courtesy of French label Hands In The Dark.

Will your contribution be going towards a printed publication? Nope!

We ceased printing REDEFINE in 2008, marking the beginning of a move towards a more environmentally-sustainable creation. In 2012, we closed our PO Box to discourage physical submissions completely, Save for occasional artistic items, our IndieGoGo has been limited to mostly intangible prizes for the exact same reason.

Art can often be directly influenced by things outside of art, whether they be the social sciences, science, mathematics, or the great beyond. We work to uncover those motivations, to show that the arts mutually informs and is informed by all walks of life.



La Dispute Band Interview: It’s Like Medicine. It’s Self Discovery. __ LITERATURE + RELIGION
How Vladimir Nabokov’s literary works, a Christian upbringing, and the socioeconomic climate of Detroit can influence one's lyrical output.

The Love Song of R. Buckminster Fuller Live Review __ PHILOSOPHY + HISTORY + AUDIO-VISUAL
The life of inventor and environmentalist R. Buckminster Fuller, in a live “documentary” with narration from Sam Green and music from Yo La Tengo.

Compare & Contrast: Mao Zedong In Art, Then And Now __ POLITICS + SOCIOLOGY + MULTICULTURAL
The portrayal of Communist leader Mao Zedong is viewed by comparing and contrasting art from Mao's era to Andy Warhol to now.

Alexis Arnold Artist Interview: Crystallizing The Present __ SCIENCE + LITERATURE
Borax and crystal formations help create literature-inspired artistic sculptures.

Prince Rama Band Interview: Utopia of the Now Age Manifesto __ PHILOSOPHY + SPIRITUALITY
A musician-crafted manifesto on time-space, performance and performer exchanges, and concepts of spirituality.

Celestial Summer: A Compilation to Reinterpret Space __ SCIENCE
Multiple musicians are given the task of building songs for a single compilation, using space recordings from NASA as a foundation.

Gardens & Villa Band Interview: Naturally Mystical __ LITERATURE + PHILOSOPHY + SPIRITUALITY
A lyrical analysis offers hints into how literature, philosophy, and spirituality can play a key role in indie pop music.

Every year, REDEFINE hosts multiple events in Portland, Seattle, New York, Austin, or over the internet, which are always low-cost, mostly DIY, and sometimes all-ages. Each of the events is driven by a different philosophical focus, but all work to highlight the ways in which different art forms and divergent communities can come together.



Mystical & Spiritual Ideas in Modern Music: SXSW 2013 Panel Pitch __ PHILOSOPHY + SPIRITUALITY
A visual exploration of how creation is influenced when musicians have strong foundations in the metaphysical, citing influences from John Coltrane, Philip Glass, Michael Jackson, Friedrich Nietzche, Carl Jung, and dozens more thinkers, modern and old.

Motion & Movement In Music Video __ AUDIO-VISUAL
A pair of complementary panels and open community dialogue on dance and movement in music videos, in collaboration with two of the West Coast's largest festivals, Bumbershoot and MusicfestNW.

BODY||MIND 2012: An Unofficial SXSW House Party __ AUDIO-VISUAL
An intimate free house party in the midst of SXSW madness that focused on psychedelia of all kinds by engaging the body in dance rhythms and the mind through psyche-altering compositions.

Protect Creative Content Creation; Join REDEFINE In SOPA/PIPA Blackout __ POLITICS
An online call to mobilize music blogs and publications to protest against SOPA and PIPA in a collective stand.

Intuitive Navigation __ AUDIO-VISUAL
"Holocene gets dressed up as an empyrean dreamworld tonight for Redefine Magazine's Intuitive Navigation, a cross-disciplinary indulgence of film, music, dance, wearable sculpture, and art installation. Intended to facilitate a self-reflective state of meditation for the attendee, expect ritualistic performance art and hypnotic stimuli galore. The event will be soundtracked by some of the Northwest’s most prismatic artists, who will perform in costume along with visual artists and dancers to enhance the immersive experience. Take special note of the evening’s headliner, Portland’s best bet for trance-induction: the soporifically zonked Golden Retriever." - Portland Mercury





How will my contribution be used?
Your contribution will be used tto pay writers for well-researched feature-length articles and possibly marketing to grow traffic to the site.

When will my prizes be delivered?
All prizes are on a variable timeline, though the lower-tier prizes should be distributed fairly quickly. The custom projects will take longer, particularly if they are articles that involve coordination on the website and with writers.

How can I help if I don't have much to give?

  • Share our IndieGoGo project on social networks.
    You can use this link -- -- and we also have accounts on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Vimeo, and YouTube.

  • Offer ideas.
    We are always looking for like-minded individuals and organizations to collaborate with. Please write us at letters@redefinemag.com with any thoughts or suggestions!

  • Donate services or spaces.
    We are housed on a Wordpress framework and can handle most design and programming problems in-house, but any additional expertise would be helpful in growing our site in more interesting and customized ways. We would also love to work with any bands, venues, or labels who might be interested in partnering.

We are housed on a Wordpress framework and can handle most design and programming problems in-house, but any additional expertise would be helpful in growing our site in more interesting and customized ways. We would also love to work with any bands, venues, or labels who might be interested in partnering.

story:
The Khanyisa Psychoactive Healing Garden Project

A Better Life through Traditional Knowledge


What is the project about and what inspired the project?

The aim of this exciting new project is to grow and showcase a unique garden of plants used in South African traditional medicine that are effective in treating mental illness and nervous disease, and poorly known in the West. Over 300 species have been reported from the fieldwork by the author as having uses to treat insomnia, depression and conditions such as epilepsy and anxiety (Sobiecki, 2002). These plants and their uses hold many keys for us to understand and treat mental illness effectively (see Jeans paper on ubulawu healing medicines on ethnobotany.co.za), yet very little research has been conducted on their cultural and medicinal uses in healing consciousness.

Much of this valuable knowledge is being lost at an alarming rate with the dying of elders and healers who are not passing on the knowledge to the younger generation many of whom who have lost interest in traditional values. 

Furthermore, the World Health Organization predicts that by 2020 depression will be the second leading cause of disease burden in the world. This is a scary statistic. Despite all the advantages of western technology, it is clear that we are all struggling more than ever to deal effectively with the stresses and challenges of modern day living. Therefore, there is a great need for places for healing, personal development and health promotion in our modern world today.

Together, these reasons inspired in my to create a garden that will serve not only to research these important yet misunderstood medicinal plants, but that will also provide a unique space in which people can heal in the garden. “Khanyisa” means illumination and describes the effects of some of the South African traditional plant medicines to uplift and revitalize the mind.

By resurfacing and using this African traditional medicinal plant knowledge into our daily lives can help us meet the new challenges we face today with stress and depression.

We are seeking to secure funding for this innovative and sustainably driven project and have launched this campaign to raise funds personally to establish the project. 

With your help we can establish the pilot Khanyisa Psychoactive Healing Garden to apply the healing benefits of South African medicinal plant knowledge to all cultural groups. 

Thus, the Vision is to create a psychoactive plant garden that can stimulate research, healing and conservation of these plants while encouraging people to benefit from this traditional holistic healing knowledge. 

The garden and the healing spaces will serve other uses too in the future:

  • To grow organic healing plant medicines for healing use. There are many South African plants that have equivalent and even stronger healing properties than those of ginseng, valerian, chamomile etc.
  • To learn how to use holistic medicines such as ubulawu, nutritional therapy and Qi Gong through expert guidance and mentoring at the garden.
  • To have access to the research findings from the project, e.g., bi-annual research bulletins, and to develop conservation strategies to protect the remaining wild populations of the plants.


Thus, the Khanyisa psychoactive healing garden will provide a unique opportunity to heal with plants in an integrated way, by having access to a uniquely designed plant healing space, learning about holistic medicine and African healing plants, while also being able to learn about what the research findings are.

How you can help?

By making whatever contribution you like (there are no minimums) one can even make a 5$ contribution if you want, you will be supporting the establishment of this research and healing garden. Do see the perks on offer and their equivalent amounts as contributions. For those in South Africa you can make a contribution through indiegogo or directly into the South African business account. Please email me at phytoalchemist@gmail.com for the banking details if you would like to contribute that way. Ps, if you want a perk, the perks will still apply in this case!

What is the money for?

1. Establishing the garden in the right area.

We have already identified two very promising sites where the pilot garden can be established, (Umphakatsi eco-village, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa, and Magwa Falls, Transkei). We still need to conduct a feasibility assessment at one of the sites (2 months) and then assess the findings together in terms of accessibility, growing conditions and richness of indigenous knowledge.

2. Constructing a research base camp from which to establish the Khanyisa plant healing space and garden.

Once the site is selected, we will construct a basic research rondavel (building) that will be used as a base camp from which to establish the garden and healing space and to conduct the anthropological fieldwork to document the indigenous plant use of the surrounding area. The building will also serve as a plant material collection, preparation and plant identification space (plant voucher specimens), and seed collection and storage facility.

3. Creating the Khanyisa plant healing space and garden.

Using permaculture design, the plant space will be designed to be a healing incubator being surrounded by African healing plants. Locally sourced materials such as clay and straw will be used to construct the building with a design to facilitate nursery warmth and plant growth and relaxation and healing for people who need to rest and recover from illness and disease. The healing space will be built with the help of local community members and will encourage their active participation in the design.

4. Conducting research, healing and ethnotourism activities for viable and sustainable income generation.

The country’s wild medicinal plant resources are fast being depleted and therefore strategies are urgently needed to encourage a working model for their sustainable use and conservation through South African and international stakeholder participation, that the project will incept.

5. Healing and ethno-tourism: The project aims to create socially and environmentally responsible jobs for the local African communities related to the gardens planned ethno-tourism activities, e.g., garden assistants, medicinal plant tour guides, healing retreat and workshop assistants etc, thereby helping to support the economic growth of the local communities. No such psychoactive plant garden exits in Southern Africa and thus this healing garden project will serve as a unique site for the preservation of threatened South African indigenous plant and cultural knowledge. 

What if we dont meet the target?

If we only meet a proportion of the target the money collected will still go towards establishing the garden in terms of site analysis or garden design etc.

Benefits you get from supporting the project?

There are many health promotion perks on offer from skype health consultations to improve your health (Jean is a qualified nutritionist too), to both western and African medicinal plant factsheets, holistic care of the nervous system guidelines, and health and psychoactive plant use Q and A’s, while also free stays at the garden.

The factors that will promote the success of the project. 

  • Being passionate about using and teaching people about African and other holistic medicine-this is my calling.
  • Being a regular writer for the South African popular press.One of the few specialist researchers on South African psychoactive medicinal plants.
  • A unique ethnobotany website in South Africa and facebook groups.
  • Producing original academic publications on this subject and connecting with researchers abroad through conferences and
  • Holding numerous public workshops on holistic medicine and plant use....

Demand and skills:

  • Furthermore, with the rapidly growing international interest in South African psychoactive plants and traditional medicine I will use the various skills and knowledge I have acquired to train up a local community project management team that will ensure the continued sustainable growth and success of the project.

About my journey with African healing plants

I have had an interest in plants, nature and mind from an early age that took me to self studying plants and medicines wherever I could. I studied ethnobotany at University and began fieldwork to find out what plants were being used by the traditional healers to open and heal the mind in their rituals. I documented over 300 species from the old literature, being used to treat many conditions, such as insomnia, depression through to dementia.

I learnt from my teacher Mrs. Letty Maponya about how South African psychoactive plants called ubulawu can be used to relax and boost the nervous system in a slow and gradual process.

After Letty’s passing in 2013, I experienced a very difficult personal stage in my life which took me into being ill. During this illness in 2013, I had the vision to create the Khanyisa Psychoactive Healing Garden that was to inspire new light in me.

Future Scope

Psychoactive plant research in South Africa has an exciting future, from developing new synergy medicines to treat and heal depression, post traumatic stress disorder and other mental illness, while also being used for personal spiritual growth and development. Further, African psychoactive plants can be used by all members of society as holistic medicine to help clean the body and balance the mind, and for this we need education, plant conservatories and healing retreats where people from all cultures can learn and apply this healing knowledge themselves, beginning a new relationship with African plants forgotten in the West!

It is my passion and vision of the Khanyisa psychoactive healing garden to: promote African traditional medicinal healing knowledge and well-being to all cultural groups. By reconnecting to traditional knowledge of nature, plants and healing we have the opportunity to heal ourselves and have a better life! 

Other ways you can helpIf you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help, please spread the word:

  • Share the link to our campaign on Facebook, tweet it to your followers, email it to your friends, and tell your friends who are interested in natural medicine. It will all help us into the future of the project.
  • Keep in touch through the Khanyisa psychoactive plant garden facebook group. You can be with us every step of the way.       

I hope to see you in the near future at the Khanyisa Psychoactive Healing Garden!

Thank you so much for your support!

Jean and Sarah

J.F. Sobiecki, B.Sc. (Hons.), (M.A. Anthropology, in progress), (UJ), project driver, is an ethnobotanist, natural medicines healer and research associate with the University of Johannesburg. He has training in ethnobotany, medical anthropology, permaculture and clinical nutrition. Jean has had a life-long calling to healing with medicinal plants, the knowledge of which he gained through: self study of nature, books, degrees and learning from indigenous South African and South American healers. He has conducted original research on the use of psychoactive plants (those affecting the nervous system) in South African traditional medicine for over 14 years and has published a number of papers on his research: www.ethnobotany.co.za. He is also a qualified nutritionist and has run a private nutritional consultancy practice. Jean is passionate about his work studying and teaching about the importance of medicinal plants, whole foods and other holistic medicine for health and healing. See http://www.phytoalchemy.co.za

Sarah Tobhi Motha, (M.A. intern human rights law), founder of Umphakatsi Peace Ecovillage, is the coordinator at the Human Rights Education Centre in South Africa. Her working experience ranges from: being a school teacher at Imbuzini village on the border of Mozambique and South Africa, Community Educator to a Research Coordinator on Youth Cooperatives. She is a former HRE Coordinator for Amnesty International South Africa under a REAP funded project and is completing her PhD on sustainable ecovillage design. +27 079 766 5803, sarahmotha@gmail.com

References:

Sobiecki J.F. The intersection of culture and science in South African traditional medicine. Indo-Pacific Journal of Phenomenology. (2014 in press).

Sobiecki J.F. Review on psychoactive plant research from southern Africa. (2013 in press). 

Sobiecki J.F. Psychoactive ubulawu medicines and healing dynamics in the initiation process of Southern Bantu diviners. (2012). Journal of Psychoactive Drugs. 44:3, 216-223.

Sobiecki J.F. A review of plants used in divination in Southern Africa and their psychoactive effects. (2008). South African Humanities. 20: 333–351.

Sobiecki J.F. A preliminary inventory of plants used for psychoactive purposes in southern African healing traditions. (2002). Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa. 57(1), 1-24.

story:
The Novel

If you believe in the importance of one's ethnic heritage, you'll want to support the fundraising for this novel.

Meet Alex, a young successful America businessman, who for most of his life, is disconnected from his Igorot-highlander heritage. One day after a strange turn of events involving his father's death, he is catapulted back to his native highlands in the Philippine Cordillera Mountains where he embarks on a journey that has him colliding with his estranged heritage in ways he never imagined.  Follow him as he spirals through Igorot, Japanese and American adventures that ultimately bestow him with certain life changing values that will forever alter his life in the most positive way by teaching him that "there is more to life than being happy."

 

 

Your Support & Its Impact

Your support will help share the culture of Igorot highlanders in the Philippines, who have successfully withstood nearly 400 years of colonization attempts from Spain as well as attempts from Japan and other invaders.  Many Filipinos have heard about us, but for the most part, the world knows little about us.  

Most important, your support can help make an impact on how people view the importance of ethnic heritage.  Readers will be inspired to take stock in their own ethnic background; whether it is of one ethnicity or a combination of several.  

The migration of people from their homelands to foreign lands continues to bring about an increase weakening of appreciation for one's own heritage. This is especially true in western societies where assimilation tends to pull people further away from their ethnic heritage.  Many become disconnected with the tangibles that make up their ethnicity such as language and traditions, but worse than this are those who are not connected with the intangible qualities that are at the root of all that is good in one's heritage.  One's heritage is a source that often overlooked as a tool for helping people become the best they can be in all aspects of their lives. 

Fundraising

Thanks to the financial support of close family members, the manuscript is now complete along with some of its pre-marketing campaign and the purchase of its ISBN number.

Now, at least $7,000 is needed to successfully publish the book.  Funds will go towards:

  • Editing ($5,000)
    • Substantive Developmental Editing by Editor (most important)
    • Copy Editing by Editor (grammar, spelling and such)
  • Paperback and hardcover printing
  • EBook Conversion / Publishing 
  • Promotional, Pre/Post Marketing
  • Distribution
  • Offsetting the Indiegogo Fee

The book will be self-published under the name, Igorot Heritage House, unless it is picked up by a traditional publisher soon after the editor is finished with it.  If the editing portion of the fundraising is not met, I will self-publish without having it edited, which is what I hope to avoid.  I am convinced that my story is too important to leave professionally unedited.  A professionally edited and well written novel has the best chances of breaking into the mainstream market that this book deserves.

For more information about the editing and publishing, please refer to the "Book's Editing and Publishing Info" file in my gallery.

 

About Me, the Author: Rexcrisanto Delson

I am a first generation Igorot, who was born in Bauko, Mountain Province in the Philippines and immigrated to America at the age of four.  My late parents were also from the Mountain Province (Otucan and Guinzadan). 

I came to America speaking only my native lgorot language (Kankanaey) and knowing only my Igorot upbringing.  This quickly changed when I underwent the process of assimilation and I tried my very best to become Americanized. Unfortunately, the price of becoming American was the loss of my native tongue and temporary disconnection with my heritage.  Thanks to my late parents, whose Igorot background and stories still resonate with me and the local Igorot community in the Chicagoland area - I am now in a place of harmony with my Igorot and American culture.

My experiences with assimilation and disconnection have become the source of inspiration for writing this fantasy-fiction novel, which is the first of more to come.  As an independent writer, I strive to inspire others for the greater good.  I enjoy writing about the importance of ethnic heritage and ways people can find common ground so that the idea of unity is possible.  

I currently reside in the Chicagoland area with my wife and three children.  My dream is to someday make writing my full-time vocation.

 

Contribute by Mail or Western Union (option)

Postal Mail:

Although credit card and Paypal are the preferred mode to contribute, those more comfortable with mailing a contribution can send personal checks, money orders, cashier checks to the following address:

Contributions are now being accepted via postal mail. Personal checks, money orders and cashiers checks need to be written out to Rexcrisanto Delson. Mail contributions to:

Rexcrisanto Delson
Igorot Heritage House Publishing
P.O. Box 868
Westmont, IL 60559 USA

Western Union:

 To send via Western Union, all you need to is:
1) got to local Western Union or online at http://www.westernunion.com/Home
2) You will be asked to provide my full name (Rexcrisanto Delson) and my city (Westmont) and state (Illinois)
3) Provide me with the Transfer Control Number so I can pick it up at a local Western Union agent. You can email me the Transfer Control Number at rexcrisanto@gmail.com

Please indicate the following:

  •  Any perks you wish to elect (shown on right side of this page)
  • How you want your name to appear in the Funders tab (True full name, nickname or anonymous) 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition or lieu of financial support, here are ways you can help the book and my endeavors as a writer:

  1. Share this campaign by using Indiegogo's share tools located directly below the video.  If you have a website or blog, you can insert a campaign widget by using the html code provided in the "embed" button.
  2. Help ramp up the pre-marketing efforts by
    • Sharing the book's website with others
    • Liking and Sharing the facebook page
  3. Join the campaign team.  Your prescence is helpful.  The more the better.  Just send me a message of email me at rexcrisanto@gmail.com  and I will send you the invitation to become a part of the team.  From there, you can contribute by posting comments OR just be a silent partner.
  4. Help expand its platform by subscribing and sharing my other related works:
    • Subscribe to & Share my Examiner.com articles
    • Subscribe to & Share my blog
    • Share my Youtube channel (Igorotdo)
  5. Connect with me on social networks:
    • Twitter
    • Facebook
    • Linkedin
    • Google+
    • Goodreads

 

Fellow Indiegogo Campaigners:

Check out how we can help each other through our Referral Rewards Program

Substantive Developmental Editing by Editor (most important)
Copy Editing by Editor (grammar, spelling and such)


Paperback and hardcover printing
EBook Conversion / Publishing 
Promotional, Pre/Post Marketing
Distribution
Offsetting the Indiegogo Fee
The book will be self-published under the name, Igorot Heritage House, unless it is picked up by a traditional publisher soon after the editor is finished with it.  If the editing portion of the fundraising is not met, I will self-publish without having it edited, which is what I hope to avoid.  I am convinced that my story is too important to leave professionally unedited.  A professionally edited and well written novel has the best chances of breaking into the mainstream market that this book deserves.
For more information about the editing and publishing, please refer to the "Book's Editing and Publishing Info" file in my gallery.
 
About Me, the Author: Rexcrisanto Delson
I am a first generation Igorot, who was born in Bauko, Mountain Province in the Philippines and immigrated to America at the age of four.  My late parents were also from the Mountain Province (Otucan and Guinzadan). 
I came to America speaking only my native lgorot language (Kankanaey) and knowing only my Igorot upbringing.  This quickly changed when I underwent the process of assimilation and I tried my very best to become Americanized. Unfortunately, the price of becoming American was the loss of my native tongue and temporary disconnection with my heritage.  Thanks to my late parents, whose Igorot background and stories still resonate with me and the local Igorot community in the Chicagoland area - I am now in a place of harmony with my Igorot and American culture.
My experiences with assimilation and disconnection have become the source of inspiration for writing this fantasy-fiction novel, which is the first of more to come.  As an independent writer, I strive to inspire others for the greater good.  I enjoy writing about the importance of ethnic heritage and ways people can find common ground so that the idea of unity is possible.  
I currently reside in the Chicagoland area with my wife and three children.  My dream is to someday make writing my full-time vocation.

story:
Hi, my name is Fredrick Martin Houston, my friends know me as Marty.  I work as an Environmental Health Specialist in the State of California, but what I do for work does not define me as person, its one of the many hats I have worn over the years.  I have been a limousine driver, a houseman, a gardener, a waiter and a bartender and while I can make a mean margarita these jobs don't define me either.  I have always enjoyed telling stories and in the last four years I have found a new passion for writing.  So writing this book seems the natural thing for me to do and the next logical step.

I have spent the last 4 years living and creating this book and I need your help with the final push, editing, cover creation and publication.  Achieving this would be a dream for me and would allow me to continue on to the next book-Yes, I am a health inspector and have I got some stories to tell you! But first let me tell you how the death of a friend opened my eyes to the world and what I saw.   

I need professional help with editing my manuscript which will cost around $1500, then I need to turn this into an electronic book so I can include the pictures I took while traveling, $2500.  I would like to be able to publish in hardback for those of us that still like to feel the paper between our fingers, $3500.  And lastly, there will be traveling expenses, gas, and book signings that I may need help with,$1000.  That's it!  If I need anything else I'll pay for it myself.  With your help I know this will get done because I will owe you a debt of gratitude and the book!

This story is non-fiction which comes from my heart.  I hit a wall in 2010 but I bounced off and I am the better for it.  I love to write and can't wait to share the insane things that happened to me while I traveled in Australia but there's more.  I went to Europe to see family and friends and then came back to the states because I couldn't wait to put it all in a book.  This campaign is about helping me complete this project and putting it in the hands of strangers to help fund it because strangers helped me create it.  I have learned that strangers can be the most familiar people you will ever know.   Your contribution will complete one of the things on my bucket list, and if you don't know what that is or don't have one, for heaven's sake, look it up and start one!

Even if you can't contribute money its OK.  Download the book when I publish it and you will find the answer in yourself.  And yes that is a picture of a Cassowary. 

Spread the word, One-Way-Ticket: An Odyssey is coming soon!


Please use indiegogo tools to share the news!

story:
The Old Neighborhood World Tour and Final Research for the forthcoming
Memoir Mozos (Summer 2015)

Who Am I?

My name is Bill Hillmann, I am an author, journalist, and dedicated bull runner in Spain. My writing has appeared in The Chicago Tribune, NPR and at Salon. I’m currently writing for Playboy’s SFW site. My debut novel The Old Neighborhood (April 2014) has acquired international acclaim from The Week Magazine (UK), Resonance FM (London), The Chicago Tribune, Library Journal and Booklist.

My publisher Curbside Splendor Publishing is an award winning independent press in Chicago.

Photos of me running with the bulls in Spain have been published around the world including Life Magazine. Publications in the UK and Australia have noted my abilities as a runner. My writing on the running of the bulls has appeared in Outside Magazine, The Chicago Tribune and NPR. I’m currently working on a memoir Mozos: A Decade Running with the Bulls of Spain.

Why am I raising funds?

I want to get my The Old Neighborhood and its Spanish translation into the European and Australian market so that it can reach a wider audience. I also need to finish my research for my memoir Mozos: A Decade Running with the Bulls of Spain.

There is plenty of competition in the US book market. The Old Neighborhood has had enormous success here but we need to break into the European market. I will tour through Ten European Cities throughout three countries and Australia starting July 4th until early September.

This summer I will embark on my tenth year running with the bulls in Spain. Throughout this summer I will also travel to various bull runs in Spain including the legendary Falces in which you run down a mountainside with wild cows and Tafalla where the run takes place in near perfect silence. These runs will deepen my understanding of the tradition and expand my experience as a runner. They will also be an opportunity to interview the legendary runners of Navarra.

Here is why I need your help:

As with most indie publishing houses, once they’ve invested
in the book itself, there’s little money left to promote them the way large
publishers can, much less to send their authors on World Book Tours. With
Curbside revolutionizing the publishing world, the tour budget is minimal.

The cost is all resting on my shoulders.

The $4000 I’m hoping to raise with this campaign will only cover a portion of the cost of a World Tour. This will include air fare, hostels when I can’t find a kind soul’s couch to crash on.

For a full inventory of the costs your contribution will help to meet, check out the section below, "What your contribution will support."

The Old Neighborhood, the novel:

The Chicago Tribune recently likened The Old Neighborhood to the work of Chicago luminaries, Stuart Dybek, Gwendolyn Brooks, and Nelson Algren.

A bright and sensitive teen, Joe Walsh is the youngest in a big, mixed-race Chicago family. After Joe witnesses his heroin-addicted oldest brother commit a brutal gangland murder, his friends and loved ones systematically drag him deeper into a black pit of violence that reaches a bloody impasse when his sister begins dating a rival gang member. 

Here's the epic book trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bwRSIyHN7lA

 

What they're saying about The Old Neighborhood: 

Hillmann's evocative novel captures the gritty sights, sounds and pulse of street life in Edgewater (Chicago). —The Chicago Tribune

 A powerful rites-of-passage novel. —The Week Magazine (UK)

 Hillmann’s first novel is a sprawling, gangland coming-of-age tale… vivid and visceral… —Booklist

 A dark urban tale. —Resonance FM (London)

 A big sprawling, lacerating, steely-eyed account of one man’s
coming of age in a mixed-race Chicago family. —Library Journal

 A raucous but soulful account of growing up on the mean streets of Chicago, and the choices kids are forced to make on a daily basis. This cool, incendiary rites of passage novel is the real deal. —Irvine Welsh, author of Trainspotting

 Hillmann’s prose is sharp, his dialogue is righteous and the F-word hits the
reader square in the face like belt-fed .50 caliber ammunition. The Old Neighborhood  is a wonderful first novel. —Thom Jones, author of The Pugilist At Rest

Tough and real and filled with a remarkably interesting cast of characters,
this is a novel in the great Chicago tradition. Nelson Algren would have loved
it, as I do. —Rick Kogan, Chicago Tribune senior writer & columnist, WGN Radio host, author, and Chicago legend

Bill Hillmann’s The Old Neighborhood is like a right hook to the chin
with brass knuckles, crackling with both bravery and urgency. Brilliantly
evoking Nelson Algren’s Neon Wilderness and Richard Price’s The
Wanderers, the novel is unflinchingly honest in its depictions of class and
race, a deft portrait of our sometimes-less-than-fair city. —Joe Meno, author of Hairstyles of the Damned

Bill Hillmann writes with a furious humanity and wide open heart. —Tony Fitzpatrick, renowned artist and author 

The Tour

The Tour will begin at the July 6 Chupinazu opening celebration for the Fiesta de San Fermin in Pamplona. I will do three literary events in celebration of my novel one of which will be in Spanish. I will complete my decade running with the bulls in Pamplona and chronicle that fiesta and conduct interviews for Mozos.

I will fly home then voyage to Australia. There I will do several events in support of The Old Neighborhood.

Then I’ll return to England August 7th for five events throughout the country three with Irvine Welsh.

Then I’ll head north to Scotland where I will do more events.

Then I’ll return to Spain. There I will run the legendary run of Falces and the
mystical run of Tafalla. Later I will do events in Cuellar and Sanse during
their Fiestas.

Finally I will travel to Paris, France to do my final event in Early
September.

What your donation will support:

Luckily I will be traveling standby through a friend at an airline (prices are adjusted)

Pamplona, Spain (Flight) $500

Australia (Flight) $2000

England (Flight) $500

Scotland (Flight) $100

Falces/Tafalla (Flight) $150

Sanse (Bus) $50

Cuellar (Bus) $50

Paris (Fight) $150

Hostels $500

Other ways you can help:

You may not be able to contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help. I’ll love you for the rest of my life if you:

Get the word out about The Old Neighborhood me this world tour I’m heading out on and this memoir Mozos I’m writing.

Talk with other people about contributing to this fundraiser.

Buy The Old Neighborhood (Curbside Splendor) from your local Independent bookshop, Barnes & Noble or Amazon.

Thank you all for your help and good vibes, may Karma return you a hundred fold for any goodness you give.

story:
Summary 


You cannot think and remain imprison emotionally. You cannot think and remain broken. You cannot think and remain a victim.

Clarence Mason "Weaver" makes people think. Think about their circumstances and future. Clarence Mason "Weaver" is a successful motivational speaker and author but his success came from over coming a heavy burden. Struck down by a racist attack on his life, he found himself permanently disable, uneducated and without hope. Until he began to THINK. 

This book is a campaign to make young men think, it describes their lives and circumstances in details then place them into an historical comparison to slavery. He exposes why black men wear their pants down and totally disrespect women. Tribalism goes into detail of why the black community has failed to compete with society and what must happen within."Tribalism" ask hard and painfully questions then provide powerful answers of freedom.

A. Why are black men so harsh on black women?

B. Why baggy pants, crooked hats and walking a certain way?

C. "Stop Acting Smart!"  or celebrate education?

D. "Give something back to the community" or give something back to your family?

E. "Don't forget where you came from" or don't forget where you are going?

F.  Led by emotions or motivated by facts?

We have seen tremendous results with the concept of this book. A tough gang banger finding himself back during slavery. A deep self analysis into why we seem to act in contrary to our own success. We firmly believe that this book will continue the success of the ebook and the lecturers by Clarence Mason "Weaver".

However, people being abused rarely free themselves. So it will take thinking people like yourself to launch this book and the project. We have the truth, it leads us but others will not hear the truth unless we deliver it.

If we don't tell them, they won't know. If we don't lead them, they won't go!

What We Need & What You Get

We need something you can take away and share with others. We need a conversation piece with historical content to share with those who don't know where to turn. This is a tool to reach those looking to join freedom.

  • Page lay out, cover design, editing of the manuscripts are high one time cost.
  • Orders will receive an autographed copy and a free e-book version.
  • We are planning our summer tour and need this inventory to offer. It is time to start the conversation. 

The Impact

If we don't tell them, they won't know. If we don't lead them, they won't go:

  • "FREEDOM" is a destination not a lifestyle. We must free minds or there is no freedom.
  • No one is free unless all are free. This book does have an impact on the reasoning and reflection on personal behavior. Every man wants success, many do not know where it is.
  • We can either hide from the darkness or turn on the light. TRIBALISM in the hands of the seeking is a powerful tool for self reliance. However, it must be in the hands of those needing it. They need us to bring the truth.

If you cannot purchase a book

We still need to prepare materials, make videos, create workbook:

  • We are traveling, training, contributing and your donations are appreciated.
  • Pass this offer on to your friends and social media groups using the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
ME

  My name is Blake Shields Abramovitz, and I'm a yoga teacher, an artist, and a passionate meditator in the Buddhist vipassana tradition.  I don't know quite how to describe the depth of my enthusiasm for the meditative path.  It feels to me like something to live for, something I can stand behind for the duration, something more real than real, like the earth itself.   

  Lately my life has undergone a massive, all-levels transformation.  Old ways of seeing and doing things simply collapsed.  My identity as a Hollywood actor became meaningless to me.  Relationships and sources of income I had depended upon for years vanished like so many puddles on the street after a rain.  What's left are the people I love, my spiritual practices, my art, and a growing, glimmering sense that I might use what's left of my life to be of some benefit to the world, rather than to seek endlessly my own reflection in the eyes of others.


MY CAMPAIGN

  In addition to a diligent and intense daily practice, an important dimension of the meditative path is retreat.  In the retreat setting, we meditators are able to live for a time much as monastics do, committing ourselves to many hours a day of devoted practice, abiding in Noble Silence, and unsparingly facing both the intense difficulty and the indescribable sweetness which arise in our bodies, minds and hearts. 

  Shinzen Young is a teacher known for his extraordinary, almost savant-like skill at guiding students into direct first-hand experiences of spiritual liberation.  One of the eight vipassana retreats I've attended was with him, and it left me forever changed.  I felt a call; a deep surety that I was in a space where I could really do the inner work that I have needed to do for so long.  It was a revolutionary episode in my life. 

  So, I am aspiring to attend Shinzen's 2013 year-end retreat, an extended silent meditation retreat in Palos Verdes, California, which goes from December 29th until January 13th-- and answer that call.


MY HEART

  I'm launching this fundraising campaign because I feel I am at a crossroads.  On the one hand, I could continue to meditate daily, feel pretty good about it, make moderate progress, and just leave off retreats for now.  I could be sensible, prudent, taking into account the practicalities of my situation. 

  On the other hand, I could get creative, and take a leap of tremendous faith.  I could follow the fervent commands bursting from inside me, and like the Eagles say in their famous song, "Take it to the limit one more time."  For freedom, for peace, for insight, and for the benefit of all living beings. 

  The latter choice is more me.  So I am asking for the support of my community in an enterprise that I know will change me in profoundly positive ways, and, as surely as night follows day, will thereby change the world.

  Will it really change the world?  Here are some words from a person who did change the world, for all of us-- Mahatma Ghandi:

"The world of tomorrow will be, must be, a society based on non-violence.  It may seem a distant goal, an unpractical utopia.  But it is not in the least unobtainable, since it can be worked from here and now.  An individual can adopt the way of life of the future-- the non-violent way-- without having to wait for others to do so.  And if an individual can do it, cannot whole groups of individuals?  Whole nations?"


MY REQUEST

  So, what I am humbling asking for is two thousand dollars to pay the cost of the retreat and to give a few hundred to Shinzen himself, who conducts these affairs at no charge.  He merely accepts donations, gifts, at the end of the retreat. 

  Mind you, I'll be sleeping in a shared room in order to keep my costs down so I can ask as little of you as possible.  And I will not be walking away from this campaign with any funds that will not be turned over to Shinzen's organization, which rents out the retreat center in Palos Verdes, or to Shinzen himself.


MY OFFERINGS

  And I am more than willing to give back.  I am a practiced, professional vinyasa flow yoga teacher, and a meditator with years of experience.  I'd be thrilled to come to you and offer guided meditation sessions or private yoga classes in return for your generosity.  If you've never meditated or practiced yoga asana, I could serve as a quality introduction to either of these deeply valuable practices.  If you have a practice already, then (assuming it is not more advanced than my own!), I could help you to deepen it.

  Now, if I don't reach my entire goal, I hope still to be able to make the retreat by coming up with the remaining funds in other ways.  However, if I don't end up being able to make it (sigh!), I will refund each of you for every dollar you donated.


MY PROMISE

  The meditative path is in a very deep sense a journey of unwinding what is tight inside, of becoming less bitter, less stuck. 

  The Buddha said this:  "There is no way to peace.  Peace is the way." 

  I promise you that if you help me attend this retreat, I will practice peace while I am there, and then bring that peace back into our world in concrete ways.

  Every time I've attended a residential meditation retreat, I've come away from it permanently changed for the better.  I've become a more authentic yoga teacher, a deeper meditator, a wiser writer, a more generous friend, a more forgiving soul.  In short, I've had more to give.

  So, your gift will have a direct, real and super positive impact not only on me personally, but on our whole extended community as well!


LASTLY

If you can’t contribute financially, that doesn’t mean you can’t still help!  You can re-post to your Facebook page and help me get the word out.  I would be sooooo appreciative of any efforts you make on my behalf! 

Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you, and many blessings of peace!

  My name is Blake Shields Abramovitz, and I'm a yoga teacher, an 
artist, and a passionate meditator in the Buddhist vipassana tradition.
